authors.name: Sima Guang
authors.description: Great historian and statesman of the Northern Song, author of the Zizhi Tongjian.

authors.name: Wang Dingbao
authors.description: Five Dynasties scholar who compiled the most important source on Tang dynasty examination culture.

authors.name: Sun Guangxian
authors.description: Five Dynasties official and prolific biji writer covering late Tang and Five Dynasties anecdotes.

authors.name: Liu Xin / Ge Hong (attr.)
authors.description: Authorship disputed between Han dynasty Liu Xin and Jin dynasty Ge Hong.

authors.name: Xuan Ding
authors.description: Late Qing writer of classical tales in the Liaozhai tradition.

authors.name: Xie Zhaozhe
authors.description: Ming encyclopedist and official, author of the monumental Wuzazu.

authors.name: Wang Jia
authors.description: Jin dynasty Daoist scholar and collector of myths and supernatural tales.

authors.name: Zhang Dai
authors.description: One of the greatest Chinese essayists, known for lyrical nostalgia for the vanished Ming world.

authors.name: Feng Menglong
authors.description: Major late Ming editor, compiler, and author of vernacular fiction and encyclopedic anthologies.

authors.name: Zhao Yi
authors.description: Leading Qing historian and poet, one of the three great historians of the Qian-Jia era.

authors.name: Xin Wenfang
authors.description: Yuan dynasty literary biographer who compiled the standard reference on Tang poets.

authors.name: Zhaolian
authors.description: Qing imperial prince (Aisin Gioro clan) who wrote insider accounts of court life and Manchu customs.

texts.title: Records Heard by the Si River (Sushui Jiwen)
texts.description: Private notes by the great historian Sima Guang recording political events and anecdotes from the Northern Song that did not make it into the Zizhi Tongjian.

texts.title: Gathered Words of the Tang (Tang Zhiyan)
texts.description: The most detailed source on Tang dynasty civil service examinations, poetry culture, and the social world of examination candidates.

texts.title: Trivial Tales from North of the Dreams (Beimeng Suoyan)
texts.description: Important biji covering late Tang through Five Dynasties anecdotes, politics, and literary culture across three decades of compilation.

texts.title: Miscellaneous Records of the Western Capital (Xijing Zaji)
texts.description: One of the earliest Chinese short story collections, recording court life, customs, and legends of the Western Han capital Chang'an. 129 stories.

texts.title: Records by the Autumn Lamp on Rainy Nights (Yeyu Qiudeng Lu)
texts.description: Late Qing collection of classical tales in the tradition of Liaozhai, noted for its literary polish and tragic love stories.

texts.title: Five Assorted Offerings (Wuzazu)
texts.description: Massive encyclopedic biji covering astronomy, geography, natural history, customs, and curiosities. Contains the earliest known mention of rock-paper-scissors.

texts.title: Records of Things Gleaned (Shiyi Ji)
texts.description: Important early collection of myths, legends, and supernatural tales spanning from mythological antiquity to the Jin dynasty. Includes descriptions of Penglai and Kunlun.

texts.title: Searching for West Lake in Dreams (Xihu Mengxun)
texts.description: Zhang Dai's lyrical guide to West Lake in Hangzhou, written decades after the Ming collapse. 72 essays organized by geographic route. Only partial translations exist in anthologies.

texts.title: The Wisdom Sack (Zhinang)
texts.description: Massive anthology of 1,238 stories of stratagems and wit from Chinese history, organized by type of wisdom. Feng Menglong's most scholarly compilation.

texts.title: History of Love (Qingshi)
texts.description: The largest anthology of love stories in Chinese literature, with 870+ stories drawn from official histories, biji, and fiction. Organized into 24 categories of love and passion.

texts.title: Studies at Leisure by the Staircase (Gaiyu Congkao)
texts.description: Major work of Qing evidential scholarship investigating origins of customs, institutions, and historical claims. Zhao Yi was one of the three leading historians of the Qian-Jia era.

texts.title: Biographies of Talented Men of the Tang (Tang Caizi Zhuan)
texts.description: The most important source for biographies of Tang dynasty poets. Contains entries for 398 poets arranged by quality and era.

texts.title: Survey of Jokes Past and Present (Gujin Tangai)
texts.description: Curated anthology of witticisms and satirical anecdotes from Chinese history, organized into 36 categories. Companion volume to Zhinang and Qingshi.

texts.title: The Night Ferry (Yehangchuan)
texts.description: A witty encyclopedic compendium covering 20 categories from astronomy to botany with 4,000+ entries, meant as conversational reference for educated travelers on night boats.

texts.title: Seven Swords and Thirteen Heroes (Qijian Shisan Xia)
texts.description: One of the most popular late Qing martial arts novels, set during the Zhengde reign. Features a band of righteous swordsmen suppressing a princely rebellion.

texts.title: Random Records from the Whistling Pavilion (Xiaoting Zalu)
texts.description: Written by a Qing imperial prince (Aisin Gioro clan), this biji offers insider accounts of Qing court politics, Manchu customs, and Bannerman life unavailable from any other source.
